hints.content: Start by understanding the structure of an N-ary tree. Each node can have zero or more children. This is different from a binary tree where each node has at most two children.
The diameter of a tree is defined as the length of the longest path between any two nodes. Remember that this path may not necessarily pass through the root.
Consider how you would traverse the tree. Depth-first search (DFS) or breadth-first search (BFS) are both valid approaches to explore all nodes.
When calculating the diameter, think about the height of the subtrees. The longest path could involve the heights of two different subtrees of a node.
While traversing, keep track of the maximum diameter found so far. You can update this value whenever you find a longer path.
You might want to create a helper function that returns both the height of the tree and updates the diameter. This way, you can calculate the height of each subtree efficiently.
Consider edge cases such as an empty tree or a tree with only one node. What should the diameter be in these cases?
Remember that the diameter is defined in terms of the number of edges, not the number of nodes. Make sure your calculations reflect this.
When implementing your solution, think about how you will handle the null values in the input tree representation. These represent missing children.

To finalize your approach, you could implement a recursive function that computes the height of each node while checking and updating the diameter at each step. This function should return the height of the current node.

questionNotes: The input is given as a level-order traversal of the tree, where 'null' indicates no child for that position.
The diameter is measured in edges, not nodes.
An empty tree should return a diameter of 0.
A single-node tree should also return a diameter of 0.
